01.text: Jesus tells a parable about wise and foolish virgins to illustrate that his disciples should be prepared for his return. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]])

01.ref: the kingdom of heaven will be like
01.text: Here "kingdom of heaven" refers to God's rule as king. The phrase "kingdom of heaven" is used only in Matthew. If possible, use "heaven" in your translation. AT: "when our God in heaven shows himself to be king, it will be like." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:13:24|13:24]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
These could have been 1) lamps or 2) torches made by putting cloth around the end of a stick and wetting the cloth with oil.

01.ref: did not take any oil with them
01.text: "had with them only the oil in their lamps"

05.text: This word is used here to mark a break in the main storyline. Here Jesus starts to tell a new part of the story.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "while the bridegroom was taking a long time to arrive" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

07.text: "adjusted their lamps so they would burn brightly"

07.ref: The foolish said to the wise
07.text: These nominal adjectives can be stated as adjectives. AT: "The foolish virgins said to the wise virgins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
This is an idiom. AT: "the fire in our lamps is about to burn out" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

10.text: Jesus concludes the parable about the ten virgins. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]])
The understood information can be stated clearly. AT: "to buy more oil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
These are the virgins who had extra oil.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "the servants shut the door" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This implicit information can be stated explicitly. AT: "open the door for us so we can come inside" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"I tell you the truth." This adds emphasis to what the master says next.
"I do not know who you are." This is the end of the parable.

10.ref: you do not know the day or the hour
10.text: Here "day" and "hour" refer to an exact time. The implied information can be stated explicitly. AT: "you do not know the exact time when the Son of Man will return" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

14.text: Jesus tells a parable about faithful and unfaithful servants to illustrate that his disciples should remain faithful during his absence and be prepared for his return. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]])
"was ready to go" or "was to go soon"

14.ref: gave over to them his wealth
14.text: "put them in charge of his wealth"

A "talent" was worth twenty years' wages. Avoid translating this into modern money. The parable is comparing the relative amounts of five, two, and one, as well as the large amount of wealth involved. AT: "five bags of gold" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bmoney]])
The implicit information can be stated explicitly. AT: "according to each servant's skill in managing wealth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"and out of his investments, he earned another five talents"

17.text: Jesus continues telling a parable about the servants and the talents. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bmoney]])

19.text: Jesus continues telling the parable about the servants and the talents. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bmoney]])
This word is used here to mark a break in the main storyline. Here Jesus starts to tell a new part of the story.

19.ref: I have made five talents more

19.text: A "talent" was worth twenty years' wages. Avoid translating this into modern money. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:25:14|25:15]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bmoney]])

"You have done well" or "You have done right." Your culture might have an expression that a master (or someone in authority) would use to show that he approves of what his servant (or someone under him) has done.

19.ref: Enter into the joy of your master
19.text: The phrase "Enter into the joy" is an idiom. Also, the master is speaking about himself in the third person. AT: "Come and be happy with me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

22.text: Jesus continues telling the parable about the servants and the talents. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bmoney]])

22.ref: I have made two more talents

22.text: "You have done well" or "You have done right." Your culture might have an expression that a master (or someone in authority) would use to show that he approves of what his servant (or someone under him) has done. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:25:19|25:21]].

22.ref: Enter into the joy of your master
22.text: The phrase "Enter into the joy" is an idiom. Also, the master is speaking about himself in the third person. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:25:19|25:21]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

24.text: Jesus continues telling the parable about the servants and the talents. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bmoney]])

24.ref: You reap where you did not sow, and you harvest where you did not scatter
24.text: These two statements mean the same thing. They refer to a farmer who gathers crops that do not belong to him. The servant uses this metaphor to accuse the master of being a ruthless businessman. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
In those days they often threw small amounts of seed around instead of planting in rows.

24.ref: See, you have here what belongs to you

26.text: Jesus continues telling a parable about the servants and the talents. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]])
"You are a wicked servant who does not want to work"

26.ref: I reap where I have not sowed and harvest where I have not scattered
26.text: These two statements mean the same thing. They refer to a farmer who gathers crops that do not belong to him. The servant uses this metaphor to accuse the master of being a ruthless businessman. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:25:24|25:24]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The understood information can be stated clearly. AT: "received back my own money" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
payment from the banker for the temporary use of the master's money

28.text: Jesus concludes the parable about the servants and the talents. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bmoney]])
The master is speaking to other servants.

A "talent" was worth twenty years' wages. Avoid translating this into modern money. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:25:14|25:15]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bmoney]])
It is implied that the person who possesses something also uses it wisely. AT: "who uses well what he has" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "God will give him more" or "I will give him more" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

28.ref: from anyone who does not possess anything
28.text: It is implied that the person does possess something but he does not use it wisely. AT: "from anyone does not use well what he has" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "God will take away" or "I will take away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

28.ref: into the outer darkness, where there will be weeping and grinding of teeth
28.text: "outside into the dark where there is only crying and grinding of teeth"

31.text: Jesus begins to tell his disciples how he will judge people when he returns at the end time.
Jesus is speaking about himself in the third person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

31.ref: Before him will be gathered all the nations
31.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "He will gather all the nations before him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here "nations" refers to people. AT: "all people from every country" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

31.ref: as a shepherd separates the sheep from the goats
31.text: Jesus uses a simile to describe how he will separate the people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

31.ref: He will place the sheep on his right hand, but the goats on his left
31.text: This is a metaphor that means the Son of Man will separate all people. He will put the righteous people at his right side, and he will put the sinners at his left side. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

34.text: Here, "the King" is another title for the Son of Man. Jesus was referring to himself in the third person. AT: "I, the King, ... my right hand" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

34.ref: Come, you who have been blessed by my Father
34.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Come, you whom my Father has blessed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is an important title for God that describes the relationship between God and Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])

34.ref: inherit the kingdom prepared for you
34.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "inherit the kingdom that God has made ready for you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

34.ref: inherit the kingdom prepared for you
34.text: Here "kingdom" refers to God's rule as king. AT: "receive the blessings of God's rule that he has planned to give you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

34.ref: from the foundation of the world

37.text: This can be stated as an adjective. AT: "the righteous people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
The understood information can be stated clearly. AT: "Or when did we see you thirsty ... Or when did we see you naked" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
This is another title for the Son of Man. Jesus is speaking about himself in the third person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
"say to those at his right hand"
"I tell you the truth." This emphasizes what the King says next.

Here "brothers" refers to anyone, male or female, who obeys the King. AT: "my brothers and sisters here" or "these who are like my brothers and sisters" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_gendernotations]])
"I consider that you did it for me"

41.text: "Then the King will." Jesus is speaking about himself in the third person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

41.ref: the eternal fire that has been prepared
41.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the eternal fire that God has prepared" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

41.ref: naked, but you did not clothe me
41.text: The words "I was" preceding "naked" are understood. AT: "I was naked, but you did not give me clothes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
The words "I was" preceding "sick" are understood. AT: "I was sick and in prison" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

44.text: Jesus finishes telling his disciples how he will judge people when he returns at the end time.
This is the end of the part of the story that began in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:23:01|23:1]], where Jesus teaches about salvation and the final judgment.
"those on his left will also answer"

44.ref: for one of the least of these
44.text: "for any of the least important ones of my people"

44.ref: you did not do for me
44.text: "I consider that you did not do it for me" or "I was really the one whom you did not help"

44.ref: These will go away into eternal punishment
44.text: "The King will send these to a place where they will receive punishment that never ends"

44.ref: but the righteous into eternal life
44.text: The understood information can be made clear. AT: "but the King will send the righteous to the place where they will live forever with God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
This nominative adjective can be stated as an adjective. AT: "the righteous people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
